hedline.hl1: Didn't I See You Here Yesterday?

abstract.p: Diners have been lining up at lunchtime to buy falafel sandwiches and other Middle Eastern items from Rainbow Cafe Falafel in New York; photo (S)

block.p: ''It's always like this,'' said Marilyn Soto, an editor at Young & Rubicam, who was in a line of more than 20 people inching their way to the counter of Rainbow Cafe Falafel, 26 East 17th Street. Just then two men joined the line. ''It's always like this,'' one said. The owner, Mohammad Jamal, confirmed that it had been like that since the day he opened -- with a line -- about six years ago.

So is it just the food? No. As Ms. Soto put it, ''The people are incredibly friendly and nice.'' No one is pressed to order fast, though most of the regulars seem to choose the falafel sandwich from the menu of more than two dozen Middle Eastern items, most displayed on the small counter inside the tiny storefront.

So is it just the food? No. As Ms. Soto put it, ''The people are incredibly friendly and nice.'' No one is pressed to order fast, though most of the regulars seem to choose the falafel sandwich from the menu of more than two dozen Middle Eastern items, most displayed on the small counter inside the tiny storefront.

The falafel sandwich is about as good as a falafel sandwich can be. A whole-wheat pita is filled first with a salad of shredded lettuce, onion and carrots. Then, ovals of crisp, spicy, freshly fried falafel are tucked inside, followed by diced tomato and a generous drizzle of tahini dressing. It costs $3. No wonder there's a line.
